docs.lead_paragraph: San Francisco lawmakers are considering making it legal for city residents to rent out their homes on sites such as Airbnb, but only if they have liability insurance and meet other requirements, a newspaper reported.

headline.main: San Francisco Considers Ending Rental Ban

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans used more health services and spent more on prescription drugs in 2013, reversing a recent trend, though greater use of cheaper generic drugs helped control spending, according to a report issued on Tuesday by a leading healthcare information company.

headline.main: U.S. Healthcare Usage and Spending Resumes Rise in 2013: Report
headline.print_headline: U.S. Healthcare Usage and Spending Resumes Rise in 2013: Report

docs.lead_paragraph: A report says that even as prescription costs have plummeted, a small slice of the population with serious illnesses is being asked to shoulder more of the cost of expensive treatments.

headline.main: Prices Soaring for Specialty Drugs, Researchers Find
headline.print_headline: Prices Soaring for Specialty Drugs, Researchers Find

docs.abstract: Report by IMS Institute for Healthcare Informatics, division of IMS Health, says that even as prescription drug costs have plummeted, small slice of population with serious illnesses is being asked to shoulder more of cost of expensive treatments; findings echo conclusions of other reports that predict spending on so-called specialty drugs will continue to rise.
docs.snippet: A report says that even as prescription costs have plummeted, a small slice of the population with serious illnesses is being asked to shoulder more of the cost of expensive treatments.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Congressional Budget Office report shows the Affordable Care Act costing less in part because of the broad slowdown in the growth of health care costs.

headline.main: Budget Office Lowers Estimate for the Cost of Expanding Health Coverage
headline.print_headline: Budget Office Lowers Estimate for the Cost of Expanding Health Coverage

docs.abstract: Congressional Budget Office says insurance expansion under the Affordable Care Act will cost $1.383 trillion over the next decade, more than $100 billion less than previous forecasts; attributes lower cost in part to broad and persistent slowdown in growth of health care costs.
docs.snippet: A Congressional Budget Office report shows the Affordable Care Act costing less in part because of the broad slowdown in the growth of health care costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: As tax professionals help with tax returns, they are also offering advice on costs of premiums and potential fines under the Affordable Care Act.

headline.main: Tax Preparers’ New Role: Health-Coverage Advisers
headline.print_headline: Tax Preparers’ New Role: Health-Coverage Advisers

docs.abstract: Tax preparers say many of their consultations this year have also included educating clients about the tax implications of the Affordable Care Act.
